services.name: AI-Powered Predictive Maintenance
services.overview: This service utilizes machine learning to predict equipment failures in manufacturing environments before they occur. By analyzing real-time sensor data and historical maintenance records, the system identifies patterns and anomalies indicative of potential failures. This enables proactive maintenance scheduling, minimizing unscheduled downtime, reducing maintenance costs, and improving overall production efficiency. The service provides actionable insights to maintenance engineers and operations managers, allowing them to optimize maintenance strategies and resource allocation. The core of the service lies in its ability to learn from data, continuously refine its predictive models, and adapt to the specific operational characteristics of each piece of equipment.
problems_addressed: Unscheduled equipment downtime leading to production delays.
High maintenance costs associated with reactive maintenance strategies.
Inefficient resource allocation in maintenance departments.
Lack of visibility into equipment health and potential failure points.
Inability to optimize maintenance schedules based on real-time data.
target_users: Maintenance Engineers: Responsible for equipment maintenance and repair.
Operations Managers: Oversee production processes and equipment uptime.
Plant Managers: Responsible for overall plant efficiency and cost management.
core_features: Real-time Sensor Data Analysis: Continuously monitors sensor data from manufacturing equipment, including temperature, pressure, vibration, and flow rates.

Predictive Failure Modeling: Employs machine learning algorithms to predict the likelihood of equipment failures based on sensor data and historical maintenance records. Models are continuously refined and improved as new data becomes available.

Anomaly Detection: Identifies unusual patterns and anomalies in sensor data that may indicate potential equipment malfunctions. Configurable thresholds for anomaly detection based on equipment type and operating conditions.
Alerting and Notifications: Generates automated alerts and notifications when a potential equipment failure is detected. Customizable alert levels based on the severity of the predicted failure.

Maintenance Recommendation Engine: Provides recommendations for maintenance actions based on predicted failures, including specific repair tasks and suggested replacement parts. Prioritization of maintenance tasks based on criticality and potential impact on production.

Reporting and Analytics: Provides comprehensive reports and analytics on equipment health, failure predictions, and maintenance performance. Customizable dashboards for visualizing key performance indicators (KPIs) related to equipment uptime and maintenance costs.
Integration with CMMS Systems: Integrates seamlessly with existing Computerized Maintenance Management Systems (CMMS) to streamline maintenance workflows and improve data accuracy.
user_journeys: A maintenance engineer logs into the system, views a dashboard displaying the health status of all monitored equipment. An alert indicates a high probability of failure for a specific hydraulic pump within the next 72 hours. The engineer clicks on the alert to view detailed sensor data, failure prediction analysis, and recommended maintenance actions. The engineer schedules a maintenance task to replace the pump during the next scheduled downtime. The system automatically updates the CMMS system with the scheduled maintenance task. After the pump is replaced, the engineer confirms the completion of the task in the system. The system updates its historical data and refines its predictive model based on the new information.
ai_capabilities: Predictive Maintenance Model: A supervised learning model trained on historical sensor data and maintenance records to predict equipment failures. Algorithms such as Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) are considered. The model outputs a probability score indicating the likelihood of failure within a specified time window.

Anomaly Detection Model: An unsupervised learning model trained on normal operating data to identify unusual patterns and anomalies. Algorithms such as One-Class SVM, Isolation Forest, and Autoencoders are considered. The model outputs an anomaly score indicating the degree of deviation from normal operating conditions.

Model Selection: The optimal model is chosen based on performance metrics such as precision, recall, F1-score, and AUC. Cross-validation techniques are used to ensure model generalizability.  Consider fine-tuning a pre-trained time-series model for faster results and reduced data requirements.

Embeddings and Vector Search: Sensor data can be embedded into a vector space to identify similar historical failure patterns. Vector search enables the identification of equipment with similar operating profiles and potential failure modes. Use embeddings from time-series models.
OpenAI Models: For interpreting maintenance logs and generating more natural language recommendations, integrate OpenAI's GPT models.

input_data_types: Sensor data (temperature, pressure, vibration, flow rate, etc.)
Historical maintenance records (repair dates, replacement parts, failure codes)
Equipment specifications (make, model, serial number, operating parameters)
data_schema_recommendations: Sensor Data Table: (timestamp, equipment_id, sensor_type, sensor_value)
Maintenance Records Table: (equipment_id, repair_date, failure_code, parts_replaced, downtime)
Equipment Specifications Table: (equipment_id, make, model, serial_number, operating_parameters)
Alerts Table: (timestamp, equipment_id, alert_type, severity, description)
data_requirements.privacy_and_compliance: Data privacy regulations such as GDPR and CCPA must be considered. Ensure that sensor data is anonymized and securely stored. Compliance with industry-specific regulations related to data collection and usage (e.g., FDA regulations for pharmaceutical manufacturing).

required_integrations: CMMS systems (e.g., SAP PM, IBM Maximo, Infor EAM)
SCADA systems (e.g., Siemens WinCC, Wonderware System Platform)
PLC systems (e.g., Siemens SIMATIC, Allen-Bradley ControlLogix)
IoT platforms (e.g., AWS IoT, Azure IoT Hub)
Email providers (e.g., SendGrid, Mailgun) for alert notifications
Analytics tools (e.g., Google Analytics, Mixpanel) for tracking user engagement
integration_plan.authentication_strategy: JWT (JSON Web Tokens) for secure API access. OAuth 2.0 for integration with third-party systems. Consider Clerk or Auth0 for user authentication and authorization management.

technical_specifications.architecture: The system follows a microservices architecture, with separate services for data ingestion, data processing, model training, prediction, alerting, and reporting.  The frontend provides a user interface for monitoring equipment health and managing maintenance tasks. Data flows from equipment sensors through an ingestion pipeline to a data lake. The predictive models are trained on this data and deployed to a prediction service. The prediction service generates alerts that are displayed on the frontend and sent to relevant personnel via email.

recommended_tech_stack.frontend: Next.js 14 App Router, TailwindCSS, shadcn/ui, Vercel conventions
recommended_tech_stack.backend: Node.js / Next.js server actions / Vercel serverless functions with REST API for communication
recommended_tech_stack.database: Planetscale / Supabase / PostgreSQL with TimescaleDB extension for time-series data storage
recommended_tech_stack.storage: Supabase storage / AWS S3 / Vercel Blob for storing model artifacts and historical data
recommended_tech_stack.AI: OpenAI API for natural language processing, Python with scikit-learn, TensorFlow, or PyTorch for machine learning, Pinecone/Supabase vectors for vector search
recommended_tech_stack.APIs: REST APIs for communication between microservices and the frontend.
recommended_tech_stack.CI_CD: GitHub â†’ Vercel automatic deploy pipeline for continuous integration and continuous deployment.

API_design: GET /equipment/{equipment_id}/health: Returns the health status of a specific piece of equipment, including sensor data, failure predictions, and maintenance recommendations.
POST /alerts: Creates a new alert for a potential equipment failure. Payload: (equipment_id, alert_type, severity, description)
GET /maintenance_tasks: Returns a list of maintenance tasks for a specific piece of equipment. Query parameters: (equipment_id, status)
POST /maintenance_tasks/{task_id}/complete: Marks a maintenance task as complete.
POST /data/ingest: Accepts sensor data and writes to the data lake. Payload includes sensor readings and metadata.
frontend_components: Equipment Health Dashboard: Displays the health status of all monitored equipment.
Equipment Details Page: Displays detailed information about a specific piece of equipment, including sensor data, failure predictions, maintenance recommendations, and historical maintenance records.
Alerts Page: Displays a list of all active alerts.
Maintenance Task Management Page: Allows maintenance engineers to manage maintenance tasks.

deployment_instructions: Environment variables: OPENAI_API_KEY, DATABASE_URL, SENSOR_DATA_API_KEY, CMMS_API_URL, SENDGRID_API_KEY, AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY, VERCEL_GIT_REPO_SLUG
Vercel deployment: Create a Vercel project connected to the GitHub repository. Configure environment variables in the Vercel project settings. Enable automatic deployments on Git push.
Runtime settings: Node.js runtime for backend services, Python runtime for data ingestion and model training, TimescaleDB for time-series data storage.

pricing_strategy: SaaS subscription tiers based on the number of monitored equipment and the level of service (e.g., Basic, Standard, Premium).
Usage-based pricing based on the volume of sensor data processed.
Per-seat pricing for access to the frontend application.
Add-ons for advanced features such as custom model training and integration with CMMS systems.
customer_segments: Large enterprises with complex manufacturing operations.
Equipment manufacturers looking to offer predictive maintenance services to their customers.

success_metrics: Accuracy of failure predictions (precision, recall, F1-score).
Number of alerts generated per month.
User engagement with the frontend application (daily/monthly active users).
